title: Massachusetts Outmigration: People Voting with Their Feet
subtitle: The ultimate accountability metric - when policies fail, people leave

quotesForSite.quote: Absent immigration, Massachusetts would already be losing population. Domestic out-migration rose again in 2025, and that's a clear signal that the state is becoming less competitive as a place to live, work, and do business.
quotesForSite.speaker: Aidan Enright

quotesForSite.quote: Massachusetts lost $10.6 billion in adjusted gross income to net out-migration between 2020 and 2022, more in those three years alone than the $10 billion it lost from 2012 to 2019.
Outmigration levels were 10 times greater in 2023 than they were in 2010.

The top driving factors behind domestic out-migration from Massachusetts are taxes, housing costs, and health care expenses, with those leaving Massachusetts tending to be younger and earn more than the state average.
quotesForSite.speaker: Mark Williams

quotesForSite.quote: 90% of CPAs surveyed indicated that their high-income clients were considering leaving Massachusetts in the next year.

bottomLine.headline: People are voting with their feet - and they're voting AGAINST Massachusetts
keyStats: 33,340 net domestic loss in 2025 - trend worsening
bottomLine.theQuestion: If Massachusetts policies were working for residents, why are so many leaving for states with lower taxes and lower costs?
